The ants have large, powerful mandibles that can snap shut with remarkable speed, allowing them to capture prey or defend their nests. This mechanism is triggered by a specialized muscle system that stores energy and releases it rapidly, enabling the jaws to close at speeds of up to 230 kilometers per hour (143 miles per hour).

These ants are typically brown or reddish-brown in color, with a slender, elongated body. They are known to be predatory, feeding on a variety of small invertebrates and other insects. Odontomachus brunneus colonies are relatively small, typically consisting of a single queen and a few hundred workers.

The species plays an important role in the ecosystem, contributing to the control of insect populations and the decomposition of organic matter. Additionally, the study of their unique trap-jaw mechanism has provided insights into the evolution of specialized adaptations in insects.
